question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answer and \textbf{show all
your work.} Simplification of the answer is not required.

Evaluate the following integral:

\[\int \frac{1}{(4+x^2)^{3/2}}\,dx\]
sols:
Using the change of variable

\[\displaystyle
x = 2\tan(\theta)\] and taking a derivative with respect to \emph{x} on
both sides we obtain

\[\displaystyle
1 = 2\sec^2(\theta) \frac{d\theta}{dx}\] and since
$1+\tan^2(\theta) = \sec^2(\theta)$ we have

\begin{align*}
(4+x^2)^{3/2} &= (4+4\tan^2(\theta))^{3/2}\\
&= 4^{3/2} (1+\tan^2(\theta))^{3/2}\\
&= 8 (\sec^2(\theta))^{3/2}\\
&= 8 \sec^3(\theta)
\end{align*} and so our integral becomes

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{1}{(4+x^2)^{3/2}}\,dx &= \int \frac{1}{8 \sec^3(\theta)} 2\sec^2(\theta) \,d\theta\\
&= \int \frac{1}{4 \sec(\theta)} \,d\theta\\
&=\frac{1}{4} \int \cos(\theta) \,d\theta\\
&= \frac{1}{4} \sin(\theta) + c
\end{align*}

Now using that

\[\frac{x}{2} = \tan(\theta) = \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\cos(\theta)}\] we
get that

\[\cos(\theta) = \frac{2\sin(\theta)}{x}\] and since
$\sin^2(\theta) + \cos^2(\theta) = 1$ we have that

\[\sin^2(\theta) + \frac{4\sin^2(\theta)}{x^2} = 1 \quad\text{so}\quad \sin^2(\theta)(1+\frac{4}{x^2}) = 1\]
and so finally we can solve for $\sin(\theta)$ and get

\[\sin(\theta) = \frac{x}{\sqrt{4 + x^2}}\] which we can now plug back
into our integral and conclude that

\[\int \frac{1}{(4+x^2)^{3/2}} \,dx = \frac{x}{4\sqrt{4 + x^2}} + c\]
